title: Ticket #1460: util_getline() in dagman should read more than 1 char at a time.
description:
I was curious about why dagman was using so much CPU when submitting basically sleep jobs, and found this in a sampled stack trace: 

(gdb) bt
#0  0xb7f99402 in __kernel_vsyscall ()
#1  0x00bbe8b3 in __read_nocancel () from /lib/libc.so.6
#2  0x00b5ee48 in _IO_file_read_internal () from /lib/libc.so.6
#3  0x00b601a0 in _IO_new_file_underflow () from /lib/libc.so.6
#4  0x00b6089b in _IO_default_uflow_internal () from /lib/libc.so.6
#5  0x00b61c0d in __uflow () from /lib/libc.so.6
#6  0x00b5b9ec in getc () from /lib/libc.so.6
#7  0x081344ed in util_getline (fp=0x3b9e7120,
    line=0xbfe3781c "Submitting job(s).\002", max=1024) at dagman_util.cpp:41
#8  0x0812024b in submit_try (args=@0xbfe37d00, condorID=@0xbfe381f8,
    type=Job::TYPE_CONDOR, prohibitMultiJobs=false) at dagman_submit.cpp:149
#9  0x08120567 in do_submit (args=@0xbfe37d00, condorID=@0xbfe381f8,
    jobType=Job::TYPE_CONDOR, prohibitMultiJobs=false) at dagman_submit.cpp:212
#10 0x0812180c in condor_submit (dm=@0x8535ee0,
    cmdFile=0x398efc68 "submit.condor", condorID=@0xbfe381f8,
    DAGNodeName=0xbe57208 "65058", DAGParentNodeNames=
      {Data = 0xbfe38170 "\230±\2169", dummy = 72 'H', Len = 199586912, capacity = 199586792, tokenBuf = 0x0, nextToken = 0xbfe38140 "¸Ä\2169"},
    names=0xbe57448, vals=0xbe57460, directory=0xbe573e8 "", logFile=0x0)
    at dagman_submit.cpp:328
#11 0x0812570f in Dag::SubmitNodeJob (this=0x9327498, dm=@0x8535ee0,
    node=0xbe57500, condorID=@0xbfe381f8) at dag.cpp:3065
#12 0x08125d8e in Dag::SubmitReadyJobs (this=0x9327498, dm=@0x8535ee0)
    at dag.cpp:1363
#13 0x0811c0ae in condor_event_timer () at dagman_main.cpp:1091
#14 0x08163671 in TimerManager::Timeout (this=0x85360a8)
    at timer_manager.cpp:416
#15 0x08146174 in DaemonCore::Driver (this=0x9301680) at daemon_core.cpp:3032
#16 0x0815ed98 in main (argc=15, argv=0xbfe38ae0) at daemon_core_main.cpp:2303
(gdb) q

We see that we're trying to submit a job.

If we follow it down to util_getline, we see this function: 

int util_getline(FILE *fp, char *line, int max) {
  int c, i = 0;

  ASSERT( EOF  == -1 );
  ASSERT( fp   != NULL );
  ASSERT( line != NULL );
  ASSERT( max  > 0 );      /* Need at least 1 slot for '\0' character */

  for (c = getc(fp) ; c != '\n' && c != EOF ; c = getc(fp)) {
    if ( !(i == 0 && isspace(c)) && (i+1 < max)) line[i++] = c;
  }
  line[i] = '\0';
  return (i==0 && c==EOF) ? EOF : i;
}

One character at a time? Lame.

If we fix this, we will reduce the CPU load of dagman most likely considerably.
remarks:
2010-Jun-17 01:01:36 by psilord:
It turns out this is pretty easy to fix and I already have a fix in my workspace of only a few lines.

If it passes the test suite on my desktop, I'll check it in, and dagman will be that much better.

2010-Jun-17 11:03:59 by psilord:
One tricky thing was the correct handling of initial whitespace, since util_getline() got rid of initial whitespace before any sscanf()s would have seen it. Turns out sscanf() understands how to do that automatically if you set the format string up properly.

Code reviewed by Kent. Checked in.

2010-Jun-17 11:43:49 by psilord:
Documented. Resolved.

2010-Jun-17 11:48:19 by psilord:
Ah, to be a little more clear about my changes, I got rid of util_getline() all together and replaced the use of it with fgets(). The former function was only used once and in a place where fgets is a much more idiomatic use.

Fixed the sscanf's which parsed the output of the condor/stork submit to be more whitespace tolerant. This is for ticket #1460. (By Peter Keller )
